dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Desktop Metal is about to raise another hundred million dollars.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Desktop Metal is about to raise another hundred million dollars.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Metal 3-D printer maker Desktop Metal raised $160 million, reaching a valuation of $1.5 billion; Markforged, which makes 3-D printers for carbon and metal, raised $82 million, hitting a valuation of $820 million; and 3-D printing service provider Fast Radius brought in $48 million, reaching a valuation of $400 million.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, from the PitchBook report, right? That would make it the second biggest deal in 3-D printing in like, what, five years?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, from the PitchBook report, right? That would make it the second biggest deal in three-D printing in like, what, five years?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Carbon's $300 million fundraise would be the largest deal of the past five years among 3-D printing companies, according to the PitchBook analysis, surpassing the same firm's earlier $200 million deal in February 2018.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, only behind Markforged's three hundred million back in 2019. But uh, it's interesting—even with that, overall funding's actually down for the sector.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, only behind Markforged's three hundred million back in twenty nineteen. But uh, it's interesting-even with that, overall funding's actually down for the sector.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: So far this year, 3-D printing companies have attracted $400 million in venture funding, half the $800 million they had garnered in the entirety of last year, and surpassing the $300 million they'd attracted the year before that, according to the PitchBook analysis.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, they mentioned it's a pittance compared to software or healthcare. Only four hundred million last year, which is way down from previous years.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, they mentioned it's a pittance compared to software or healthcare. Only four hundred million last year, which is way down from previous years.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: So far this year, 3-D printing companies have attracted $400 million in venture funding, half the $800 million they had garnered in the entirety of last year, and surpassing the $300 million they'd attracted the year before that, according to the PitchBook analysis.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But this year's already hit two hundred million, and if deals keep up, it might cross a billion for the first time in three years.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But this year's already hit two hundred million, and if deals keep up, it might cross a billion for the first time in three years.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: So far this year, 3-D printing companies have attracted $400 million in venture funding, half the $800 million they had garnered in the entirety of last year, and surpassing the $300 million they'd attracted the year before that, according to the PitchBook analysis. If deal flow continued at that rate, it would cross the billion-dollar mark for the first time in five years, even before accounting for the Carbon deal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Though, you know, it's not all sunshine—the industrial adoption has been slipping, and there just aren't many new startups popping up.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Though, you know, it's not all sunshine-the industrial adoption has been slipping, and there just aren't many new startups popping up.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While those dollars are a pittance compared to the funding numbers for healthcare or software companies, they represent a big bump up for 3-D printing, which has been gaining adoption in the industrial sector and has spawned hundreds of new startups.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: True, but Desktop Metal itself is valued at one point eight billion now, and could go up to two point two after this round.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: True, but Desktop Metal itself is valued at one point eight billion now, and could go up to two point two after this round.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Metal 3-D printer maker Desktop Metal raised $160 million, reaching a valuation of $1.5 billion; Markforged, which makes 3-D printers for carbon and metal, raised $82 million, hitting a valuation of $820 million; and 3-D printing service provider Fast Radius brought in $48 million, reaching a valuation of $400 million.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And they've got some heavy hitters backing them—Berkshire Hathaway, GV, Microsoft…
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they've got some heavy hitters backing them-Berkshire Hathaway, G V, Microsoft...

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Don't forget their partnership with Adidas—making soles for those Supernova running shoes. That's pretty cool application.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Don't forget their partnership with Adidas-making soles for those Supernova running shoes. That's pretty cool application.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Carbon is best known for its partnership with Adidas, with whom it is partnering on midsoles for the German sportswear giants Futurecraft 4D running shoes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh yeah, practical use case right there. And Carbon and Fast Radius also had big raises this year too, according to that analysis.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh yeah, practical use case right there. And Carbon and Fast Radius also had big raises this year too, according to that analysis.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Three of the top 10 deals of the past five years have occurred in the first few months of this year, according to the PitchBook analysis: Metal 3-D printer maker Desktop Metal raised $160 million, reaching a valuation of $1.5 billion; Markforged, which makes 3-D printers for carbon and metal, raised $82 million, hitting a valuation of $820 million; and 3-D printing service provider Fast Radius brought in $48 million, reaching a valuation of $400 million.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Mhm, Carbon got a hundred million, Fast Radius eighty million—so it's not just Desktop Metal carrying the torch.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Mhm, Carbon got a hundred million, Fast Radius eighty million-so it's not just Desktop Metal carrying the torch.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That's the case even before accounting for the coming $300 million fundraise from 3-D printing unicorn Carbon, which was first reported by PitchBook on Thursday.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Still, you gotta wonder if this signals a turnaround or just a few standout companies getting all the love.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Still, you gotta wonder if this signals a turnaround or just a few standout companies getting all the love.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Good point. The sector's sending mixed signals, for sure.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Good point. The sector's sending mixed signals, for sure.

artist_script:
HostA: Desktop Metal is about to raise another hundred million dollars.
HostB: Wait, from the PitchBook report, right? That would make it the second biggest deal in 3-D printing in like, what, five years?
HostA: Yeah, only behind Markforged's three hundred million back in 2019. But uh, it’s interesting—even with that, overall funding’s actually down for the sector.
HostB: Right, they mentioned it’s a pittance compared to software or healthcare. Only four hundred million last year, which is way down from previous years.
HostA: But this year’s already hit two hundred million, and if deals keep up, it might cross a billion for the first time in three years.
HostB: Though, you know, it’s not all sunshine—the industrial adoption has been slipping, and there just aren’t many new startups popping up.
HostA: True, but Desktop Metal itself is valued at one point eight billion now, and could go up to two point two after this round.
HostB: And they’ve got some heavy hitters backing them—Berkshire Hathaway, GV, Microsoft…
HostA: Don’t forget their partnership with Adidas—making soles for those Supernova running shoes. That’s pretty cool application.
HostB: Oh yeah, practical use case right there. And Carbon and Fast Radius also had big raises this year too, according to that analysis.
HostA: Mhm, Carbon got a hundred million, Fast Radius eighty million—so it’s not just Desktop Metal carrying the torch.
HostB: Still, you gotta wonder if this signals a turnaround or just a few standout companies getting all the love.
HostA: Good point. The sector’s sending mixed signals, for sure.
